Award.AwardTitle: Introducing Next Generation of STEM Students to Mesh Modeling for Simulation and Visualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports graduate and postdoctoral student participation from US universities, national labs, and non-profit research organizations to attend the 22nd International Meshing Roundtable (IMR) Conference be held in October 2013 in Orlando, FL. IMR created in 1992 is a unique conference for researchers in the field of mesh generation to exchange ideas and is also an excellent educational opportunity for students who are working on the meshing research and related applications. Potential topics for discussion in the conference include: mesh generation and modification, meshing for high-performance and distributed computing, CAD and computational geometry issues, and applications of meshing in computer graphics, finite-element analysis, computational fluid dynamics, biomedical engineering, processing of laser/CT/MRI scans, etc.
Students have the opportunity to attend a short course in meshing where the lecturers are internationally known experts in mesh generation. The instructors address practical problems for the design and implementation of both unstructured and structured grid generation. The course is ideal for graduate students that just enter the field and for advance graduate and postdoctoral students that want to expand their current skills and knowledge.
The workshop provides a forum to foster discussions mesh generation and will enable the identification of areas of common interest and potential collaboration among attendees from academia, National Laboratories, and industry. Priority will be given to students/postdocs presenting a paper or poster at the conference. The PI plans to diversify the accepted attendees' pool and attract underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Finite Element (FE) mesh generation is one of the most critical components in Computational Sciences, a third pillar (along theory and experimentation) of research and innovation in many sectors of our industry. The goal of this project is to support graduate and postdoctoral student participation from US universities, national labs, and non-profit research organizations in the 22nd  and 23rd International Meshing Roundtable (IMR) Conference, a premier conference in FE mesh generation. This project, ssupported 19 students, two of them undergraduate student, several of them female and one trans gender graduate students. Almost doubled the number of students we initially plan. The specific objectives of their participation in IMR were: (i)  to create and  strengthen new collaborations with researchers around the world,  US universities and industry in Engineering Geometry and (ii) to expose them to new ideas as well as give them the opportunity to talk to experts around  the world, get feedback and guidance related to their training and PhD/MSc work here in US. The impact of this grant is summarized in the students' ccomments, to list few: (a) "The feedback and advice I received was invaluable and helped me navigate my job hunt.", (b) "The IMR travel grant was vital to me in order to attended   the conference. As a final year graduate student, it not only provided me with the opportunity to present our work but also to network with other professionals and know about available postdoc and industry positions.", (c) "I received lots of inspiring feedback to my current research and got to know more people who works on related topics using different approaches." In summary, this project it contributes to  train and create a labor force that could lead research, development and innovation in Engineering Geometry and specifically Finite Element mesh generation. A well trained and fully informed (about the developments of research around the world) next generation of computer scientists and engineers in mesh generation helps our competitiveness  and national security.
